Hopkins' CSOS gets
$1,655,936 grant
Hopkins' Center for the Social
Organization of Schools has
received three grants totaling
S1,655,936 from the National
Institute of Education of the
Department of Health Education
and Welfare.
The largest individual aware,
for $1,059,895, was to the
Center's school organization
program, headed by Dr. James M.
McPartland, Social Relations. He
stated' that the purpose of the
program is to provide a scientific
basis for the development of new
organization forms for
elementary and secondary
schools.
Surveys
His current project involves
surveys of 35 schools with
different structures, ranging from
traditional to "open" schools;
analysis of test score data
obtained from large samples of
students; experiments with
alternative grading techniques;
and classroom experiments with
student-team instructional
techniques.
Another award, for $396,041
was made to the Center's schools
and maturity program, which is
concerned with the development
of an individual's ability to
function effectively alone as well

as interacting with others.
Ellen Greenberger, a center
research scientist who is in charge
of the program, said that its
principle objectives are to
develop a model of so-called
"psycho-social maturity, to
devise an age-related scale based
on the model for measuring
growth in students' maturity
during schooling and to study the
effects of school, family and peer
group on the maturation of the
individual."
The smallest of the three
grants, this one for $200,000 was
made to the Center's careers and
curricula program, under Dr.
John Holland, Social Relations,
the Center's director. The goal of
this program, Holland said, is to
organize current knowledge
about vocational behavior to
create vocational devices and
systems to help people adapt
more successfully to vocational
difficulties.
One of the outcomes of this
program has been the
development of a
"do-it-yourself" vocational
guidance package which an
individual of any age can test his
own aptitudes in six general
career categories that relate to six
basic personality types.

Spiro T. Agnew bade the American people farewell in a brief
television address last night, and it can only be said that they
will be better off for his departure. During his brief address, he
appeared to place part of the blame for his misfortune on the
press, the prosecutors, the system, instead of all on himself,
where it belonged. It was one of the most cynical public
speeches ever made by a political figure and it was also one of
the most pathetic.
For here was a man who had risen from obscure Baltimore
county zoning politics to a seat on the dais of the United State
Senate, a chair in the National Security Council, and the second
highest office the nation can bestow. Allegedly through most of
his quick rise, he was demanding—and getting—substantial
payments, both in money and in kind, from assorted associates,
contractors and favor seekers. He had taken oaths to support
the laws and the Constitution and he had on occasion lambasted
his critics, as an ',effete corps of impudent snobs who
characterize themselves as intellectuals." or on anoter occasion
as "nattering nabobs of negativism."
A llarge portion of the American people responded to him,
believed him and supported him, and yet he was apparently
content every moment to accept envelopes full of cash from
messengers, allegedly including one who made his drop in the
Vice-President's office next door to the White House. Every
dollar he collected for favors granted or favors promised
eventually had to be repaid from somewhere, and it usually was
from the pockets of the citizens whose laws he was sworn to
uphold.
He talked tough and he often expressed contempt for those
Americans who did not share his beliefs, but in the end he
showed he felt only contempt for all of them.

Hopkins' Center for the Social

for $1,059,895, was to the
Center's school organization
program, headed by Dr. James M.
McPartland, Social Relations. He
stated' that the purpose of the
program is to provide a scientific
basis for the development of new
organization forms for
elementary and secondary
schools.
Surveys
His current project involves
surveys of 35 schools with
different structures, ranging from
traditional to "open" schools;
analysis of test score data
obtained from large samples of
students; experiments with
alternative grading techniques;
and classroom experiments with
student-team instructional
techniques.
Another award, for $396,041
was made to the Center's schools
and maturity program, which is
concerned with the development
of an individual's ability to
function effectively alone as well

as interacting with others.
Ellen Greenberger, a center
research scientist who is in charge
of the program, said that its
principle objectives are to
develop a model of so-called
"psycho-social maturity, to
devise an age-related scale based
on the model for measuring
growth in students' maturity
during schooling and to study the
effects of school, family and peer
group on the maturation of the
individual."
The smallest of the three
grants, this one for $200,000 was
made to the Center's careers and
curricula program, under Dr.
John Holland, Social Relations,
the Center's director. The goal of
this program, Holland said, is to
organize current knowledge
about vocational behavior to
create vocational devices and
systems to help people adapt
more successfully to vocational
difficulties.
One of the outcomes of this
program has been the
development of a
"do-it-yourself" vocational
guidance package which an
individual of any age can test his
own aptitudes in six general
career categories that relate to six
basic personality types.

Spiro T. Agnew bade the American people farewell in a brief
television address last night, and it can only be said that they
will be better off for his departure. During his brief address, he
appeared to place part of the blame for his misfortune on the
press, the prosecutors, the system, instead of all on himself,

speeches ever made by a political figure and it was also one of
the most pathetic.
For here was a man who had risen from obscure Baltimore
county zoning politics to a seat on the dais of the United State
Senate, a chair in the National Security Council, and the second
highest office the nation can bestow. Allegedly through most of
his quick rise, he was demanding—and getting—substantial
payments, both in money and in kind, from assorted associates,
contractors and favor seekers. He had taken oaths to support
the laws and the Constitution and he had on occasion lambasted
his critics, as an ',effete corps of impudent snobs who
characterize themselves as intellectuals." or on anoter occasion
as "nattering nabobs of negativism."
A llarge portion of the American people responded to him,
believed him and supported him, and yet he was apparently
content every moment to accept envelopes full of cash from
messengers, allegedly including one who made his drop in the
Vice-President's office next door to the White House. Every
dollar he collected for favors granted or favors promised
eventually had to be repaid from somewhere, and it usually was
from the pockets of the citizens whose laws he was sworn to
uphold.
He talked tough and he often expressed contempt for those
Americans who did not share his beliefs, but in the end he
showed he felt only contempt for all of them.
